title: Lowey will not run for reelection
text:
The Congresswoman said she would step down at the end of her current term. | Zach Gibson/Getty Images Lowey will not run for reelection

Rep. Nita Lowey, the chair of the House Appropriations Committee, will not run for reelection, she announced Thursday.

The Congresswoman, 82, who has represented Westchester and Rockland Counties for more than three decades, said she would step down at the end of her current term.

Story Continued Below

“It is my deep honor and privilege to serve my community and my country, and I will always be grateful to the people who have entrusted me to represent them,” she said in a statement.

“I will continue working as hard as ever — with the same optimism and energy — through the end of this term in Congress.”

The longtime congresswoman’s retirement will open up a race for her seat. Mondaire Jones, a former Obama administration staffer, had already jumped into the race in a primary challenge to Lowey. Chelsea Clinton has also been rumored as a possible contender for the seat.

In a statement, Jones, who has criticized Lowey in the past, praised her years of service.

"As a trailblazer for women and minorities such as myself, Congresswoman Lowey set an example and has made it easier for people like me to run for office," Jones said, vowing to press on with his campaign, espousing democratic socialist ideals.

"We need bold, progressive leadership in Congress: guaranteed health care, a Green New Deal, student debt forgiveness, and a full restoration of the State and Local Tax Deductions (SALT) for families in Westchester and Rockland," he said. "There’s never been an openly gay, black member of Congress — because people like me don’t usually get anywhere close. But we’re about to make history.”
description: The longtime congresswoman’s retirement will open up a race for her seat.
